text:
JMeter should have a graphical indication of when it is running and when it is 
stopped.  An event should be generated for start and end of test that JMeter 
can respond to.
creator: mstover1@apache.org
kate@rapidmoney.com
text:
The non-gui driver also needs to know when a test has stopped, and exit.

It would be nice if the GUI driver had a progress bar to show how far along
the tests are.

Both drivers could indicate how far along the loop count is, and how many
remain.

creator: dim@bigpond.net.au
text:
I have just attached a patch for this that does the following:
   * In ThreadGroup, add a threadStopped() that keeps track of which threads 
have stopped.  When there are zero threads left, this method calls 
ThreadGroup.SampleQueue.stop(), which causes the thread in SampleQueue to exit.
   * In JMeterThread, when the run() method finishes, call group.threadStopped
() to indicate the thread has finished.

There is also a patch for nongui.bat to make it work.

Note that this patch assumes that each JMeterThread object is run once and only 
once.  At the moment ThreadGroup.threadCount() that is responsible for counting 
the number of threads in a group, is called in the JMeterThread constructor.  
Perhaps this would be better at the start of the run() method.  There is also 
the possibility of moving the group.threadStopped() call to a finally block in 
the run method.

I've only just started looking at the code so have done the bare minimum for 
now.

creator: mramshaw@alumni.concordia.ca
text:
My approach is different from the one Mike is taking in the 'src_1' branch.

After some head-scratching, I decided to submit mine anyway.

Like Kate, I thought about a Progress Bar. But there's no way of knowing in
advance how long each of the various test steps might take. So a progress
bar would be misleading at best. I kind of like the idea of 'ticking off'
the steps in the tree as they are executed. But I think that the best idea
may be to just add a text area (which would show the same sort of progress
messages as the command-line version).

The approach I'm taking in src_1 is similar to what Dmitri describes, but so far
has not touched any GUI functions.  Most likely, the JMeter GUI itself will
become a TestListener, and will be able to react in any desired manner to test
start/stop messages.

To get an affect like what you describe of scrolling text messages showing URL's
tested, try using the AssertionListener - it's one of the reasons I made it the
way it is.  So that I can look at it instead of the command line.

I will look at both patches more and see what I can use in the src_1 branch, so
thanks!

There is now a very simple test stop/start indicator.  Basically, a green light 
in the upper right-hand corner of JMeter lights up when JMeter is running.  I'm 
resisting anything fancy because JMeter needs to be very performance-conscious.

1.6, and we need to clean up a little.
